query: What additional resources and support services are available for social care users in southampton, including advocacy and complaints services?

retrieved_documents.content:
--

What information and services are available? You can view our directory to find services in Southampton that can offer support to carers. Advice and guidance Support for parents/carers of children with SEND Carer Aware e-learning Unpaid Carers Support Southampton Carers Together NHS - Social care and support guide Challenging Behaviour Foundation - help for carers and families Carer's Allowance Carers' support lines Dementia UK Flexible working Buzz Network - For Parent/Carers Of Disabled Children Back Your path to help and advice Self-assessment home ▼ Support for carers ▼ What information and services are available?

In this section Care information and professionals (current) Data and records Background information about Adult Social Care Wellbeing resources for care staff Adult social care professional referral Southampton Safeguarding Adults Board Data and records Southampton Safeguarding Adults Board Background information about Adult Social Care EquipMe Make life for your clients easier in three simple steps with EquipMe . Get impartial advice about tools and equipment to make daily living easier: Choose a topic Answer some questions Get advice Visit EquipMe . Refernet If your clients are in need of information advice or guidance, the best thing to do is to signpost your clients to advice and support through Refernet . This way of accessing advice offers practical, up-to-date information and advice on a wide range of topics, including: Debt Benefits Housing Legal Discrimination Employment Immigration Consumer And other problems. You can register with Rerernet once and then use the service again and again

--

Home Someone is experiencing harm, abuse or neglect Our Adult Social Care self-help page directs you to the most relevant information. Find out how adult social care services in Southampton are improving . Staying independent at home Housing Financial support Support for carers Living with a health condition or disability Support after a hospital stay or illness Safety in the home Getting out and about Help in a crisis Getting my voice heard Can’t find what you’re looking for? You can: Visit the Adult Social Care homepage Search our directory for services that might be able to help Get impartial advice about tools and equipment to make daily living easier with EquipMe

In this section Where to get support Adult care eligibility - who can get care and support? Independent living Help to stay at home Home care providers (current) Housing support for older people Southampton Day Service Summary of support available Provision : Home Care Providers Location: Own home Type of provision: Domiciliary (in home) respite Suitable for ages : 18 plus Telephone: 023 8083 2900 Description There are a small number of domiciliary care providers that have learning disabilities expertise that can offer short break services in a personalised way for people with learning disabilities and autism, providing support in people’s own homes and their community. The support is tailored around individual needs, providing bespoke packages, and also covers crisis or emergency support. All home care providers are registered and inspected by the Care Quality Commission. If you are interested in finding out more, then speak to your social worker

[Page 7 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]
What if I need ongoing care and support and who pays for it? 
If you have ongoing care and support needs which are assessed as being eligible 
for help from the Council, we will work with you to develop a personal support plan. The social worker will arrange for you to have a fnancial assessment, if you haven’t had one before. 
Depending on your fnancial circumstances, you may need to pay some or all of 
the cost of your care and support. 
If you are not eligible for services from the Council, we will give you information 
and advice about how to access care and support services for yourself. You can fnd information and services to manage your own care needs and to stay independent on the Southampton City Council website www.southampton.gov.uk. 
Some people may be eligible for NHS Continuing Healthcare. It is available to

through direct payments.
• A mixture of more than one of these options
How can I access this?
A referral can be made by a Parent/Carer or professionals working with the child via the Southampton
Children’s Resource Service team, with the consent of the child’s parent. If eligible, an assessment of needs
will be carried out by a social worker. This assessment will consider the impact of the child’s disability on them
and their parent/carer and siblings. This could result in an assessed need for additional support or respite. 
Southampton Directory  |  Children’s Resource Service
Telephone (office hours): 023 8083 3004
Out of hours: 023 8023 3344
What is the Complex Tier of Support?
Families open to the JIGSAW Children with Disabilities Team will have an assessment of needs and if eligible 
will receive an individualised Short Breaks package of support through a Personal Budget. This might be 
through;
• Individual support in the home or community (e.g. outreach)
• Family based overnight and day care

. There is also an option to purchase these via the app. EquipMe, which is available to all residents, their families and carers, provides information, advice and support on a range of topics, including health and wellbeing, daily activities, support in the home, and even support for your children. The online tool also provides impartial, detailed reports written by occupational therapists which offer easy-to-understand tips and guidance for health and care support. Councillor Lorna Fielker, Cabinet Member for Adults, Health and Housing, said: “Many people don’t know where to go to for advice and support in Southampton, or how to access the equipment they may need. I’m really pleased we’re now able to give residents greater control over their lives by enabling them to have a choice about the support they can access from organisations and agencies across Southampton

I’m moving to Southampton You can view our page about moving to Southampton to get all the information you’ll need, including Council Tax and bins information. Moving into Southampton with adult social care needs If you receive support to meet your daily living needs from your current Local Authority please ensure you have spoken to a social worker in your local area about your move. Under The Care Act 2014 it is the duty of your existing Local Authority to ensure Southampton City Council is aware of your move, has a copy of your most recent assessment and that support is put in place in a timely way to ensure your needs are met from your point of arrival. If you currently self-fund your support and have not had a recent assessment from your current Local Authority but need advice on what is available in Southampton, please see our directory of services for adults or visit our page My health makes it difficult to look after myself

5. Align approach to carers across health and social care organisations and education 
6. Explore whether the identifcation of a community hub/venues will make it easier for carers to access support when needed, including info and support, a place to meet other carers and access to replacement care. Or using existing council/NHS buildings for outreach might be helpful. 
Improving information, advice and guidance 
1. Increase the number of carers who receive information and advice from the NHS, Social Care and education, as well as from specialist carer and young carer services 
2. Develop a clear information pack and introductory sessions to share with carers. 
3. Explore different apps for Carers. Consider buying access to Carers UK ‘Digital Resource for Carers’. This would give all carers in Southampton free access to training, the Jointly app designed by Carers UK to help store and to share information and manage care and other digital support.

In this section Where to get support Adult care eligibility - who can get care and support? Independent living Help to stay at home (current) Home care providers Housing support for older people Southampton Day Service Getting help at home for yourself We have lots of services available to help and assist you in your own home, for example getting help with your personal care needs. Our aim is to help you live independently in your own home for as long as possible. Please contact us if you would like more information about the home care services we can provide. Some of them may also require an assessment and there may be associated costs. Find out how we decide who is eligible for our home care services, including getting help with your personal care needs

answer:
In Southampton, social care users have access to a variety of resources and support services, including advocacy and complaints services, though specific details on advocacy and complaints are not explicitly mentioned in the documents.

**Available Resources and Support Services:**

- **Directory of Services:** Southampton City Council provides a directory where users can find various services available to support carers and individuals with social care needs. This includes advice, guidance, and support for specific conditions such as SEND and dementia. [Source: Document 1]

- **EquipMe Tool:** This online tool offers impartial advice on tools and equipment to make daily living easier, providing support on health, wellbeing, and daily activities. [Source: Document 2, Document 7]

- **Refernet:** A service that provides practical, up-to-date information and advice on a wide range of topics including debt, benefits, housing, and more. Users can register once and access the service repeatedly. [Source: Document 2]

- **Support for Carers:** Services include Carer Aware e-learning, support lines, and flexible working options. The council is also exploring digital resources for carers, such as the Jointly app. [Source: Document 1, Document 9]

- **Home Care Providers:** There are domiciliary care providers with expertise in learning disabilities, offering personalized short break services and crisis support. [Source: Document 4]

- **Children’s Resource Service:** Provides support for children with disabilities, including assessments and short breaks. [Source: Document 6]

**Next Steps and Resources:**

- **Contact Information:** For more information or to access these services, visit the Southampton City Council website or contact the relevant departments via the provided phone numbers, such as the Children’s Resource Service at 023 8083 3004. [Source: Document 6]

- **Further Information:** Visit the Southampton City Council's adult social care homepage to explore more about available services and support options. [Source: Document 3]

The available documents don't provide specific information about advocacy and complaints services in Southampton. For more detailed inquiries, visiting the Southampton City Council website or contacting their social care department directly would be advisable.

test_metadata.prompt_template:
Please answer the following question about social care services in UK local authorities based only on the information in the provided documents.

Question: {query}

Context from relevant documents:
{context}

Instructions:
1. Provide a clear, direct answer that would help someone needing this information. If information isn't available, state: "The available documents don't provide specific information about [aspect]."

2. Synthesize information from ALL relevant documents to provide the most complete answer rather than analyzing documents individually.

3. Structure your response with:
   - A concise 1-2 sentence summary first
   - Relevant details organized in short, clear paragraphs
   - Bullet points for lists or step-by-step information
   - Bold text for key information the user should notice

4. For financial information:
   - Include exact figures, time periods, and what the funding covers
   - Present financial data clearly: "The adult social care budget is **£X million** for [time period]"

5. Always include practical next steps or resources:
   - Provide contact information, URLs, or application methods mentioned in the documents
   - Suggest where the person could find more information

6. When citing sources, use a simple format: "According to [document name/description]" or include URLs where available.

Answer:
